with predominant constipation (IBS-C)
with alternating diarrhoea and constipation (mixed forms, IBS-M)
unclassified forms |Rubric=Definition |Contributors= |Order=1}} Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) (formerly functional colopathy) is a clinical diagnosis defined by the presence of abdominal pain associated with transit disorders in the absence of any organic digestive disease. By definition, all complementary tests are normal. It is a benign but chronic pathology with a significant deterioration in quality of life. There are 4 subtypes of IBS, depending on the predominant transit. - IBS with predominant diarrhoea (IBS-D), - IBS with predominant constipation (IBS-C) - IBS with alternating diarrhoea and constipation (IBS-A) - IBS indeterminate (IBS-I), for patients who do not fall into any of the 3 subgroups

question.question: What is the primary characteristic that defines Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)?
question.option_a: Presence of abdominal pain without any organic digestive disease
question.option_b: Abdominal pain associated with weight loss
question.option_c: Abdominal pain associated with blood in stool
